nodes.text: How would changing which colleges students attend affect parental-income segregation across colleges and intergenerational income mobility in the United States?

We construct near-complete college-level statistics by linking deidentified federal tax records, Department of Education enrollment records (1098-T and Pell/NSLDS), and College Board/ACT test-score records for U.S. students born 1980–1991, focusing analyses on 1980–82 cohorts.

Parental household income is measured as mean pretax family income when child aged 15–19 using tax data and ranked into percentiles; children's earnings measured in 2014 (ages 32–34) using tax records; college attendance assigned by most-attended college ages 19–22.

We estimate three parameter sets for simulations: (i) parental income distributions by college, (ii) students' postcollege earnings conditional on parent income by college, and (iii) the share of variation in earnings due to colleges' causal effects (value-added).

We use SAT/ACT scores and race to model counterfactual reallocations: an income-neutral allocation conditional on test score, race, and state; and a need-affirmative allocation that adds score advantages to lower-income students (benchmark: +160 SAT for bottom quintile).

We estimate the fraction of college-level conditional earnings differences attributable to causal effects by regressing earnings on college fixed effects, controlling for test scores, parent income, race, high-school controls, and application-set proxies, finding high persistence of college fixed effects.

We assume as baseline that 80% of observed differences in students' earnings (conditional on test scores, race, and parental income) reflect colleges' causal effects; sensitivity analysis considers 0%–100%.
Data coverage and linkage provide near-complete rosters of Title IV college attendance and administrative measures of parent and child incomes, closely matching external aggregates (IPEDS, CPS, ACS).

SAT/ACT scores are observed for a large share of students; for missing scores (~26%) we impute within state, race, and college-tier cells using closest adult earnings analogues and validate imputation in states with universal test taking.

Parental income segregation across colleges is very high: Ivy-Plus colleges enroll far more top-1% and top-quintile children (e.g., top-1% share 14.5% at Ivy-Plus; bottom-quintile share 3.8%), and two-year/community colleges enroll many more bottom-quintile students.

Income segregation across colleges is comparable in magnitude to parental-income segregation across childhood neighborhoods (ZIP codes) of similar population size; colleges remain highly segregated after adjusting for local applicant pools.

Within a given college, differences in earnings between students from high- and low-income parents are much smaller than national differences: the nationwide rank-rank slope is ~0.29, but controlling for college fixed effects reduces this to ~0.14 and among college-goers to ~0.10; elite colleges show even flatter within-college slopes (~0.06).

There is substantial cross-college heterogeneity in mean student earnings: colleges that enroll higher shares of high-income students tend to have higher mean earnings outcomes for students (enrollment-weighted correlation ~0.78), implying between-college sorting explains much of the national parent-child gap.

Undermatching: conditional on SAT/ACT scores and state/race, higher-income students are substantially more likely to attend selective colleges; there are relatively few high-scoring low-income students (e.g., among 1300+ scorers only ~3.7% are bottom-quintile), so income-neutral allocations mainly increase middle-class shares at elite privates, not bottom-quintile shares.

Counterfactual simulations: (a) income-neutral allocations (randomize students across colleges conditional on test score, race, state) would substantially reduce segregation overall and reduce parent-child gap in reaching top quintile by about 15% under the baseline 80% causal assumption; (b) need-affirmative allocations (granting low/middle income students large score-equivalent preferences, e.g., +160 SAT to bottom quintile) would essentially equalize parental income distributions across colleges and reduce the parent-child top-quintile gap by about 25% under baseline assumptions.
